title: Average GPA
question_text:
A high school principal collects some data about students at his school. He uses his student information system to find the grade point average (GPA) of $10$ random students. The GPAs are listed below:
$$3.2, 3.7, 4.0, 2.5, 3.1, 3.5, 3.8, 3.0, 2.7, 2.5$$
This gives the principal an average GPA of $3.2$ on a $4$ point scale.
Can the principal confidently say that the average GPA of his high school is $3.2$?

choices.text: Yes, because he collected data on $10$ students.
Yes, because the data was randomly collected.
No, because the data was randomly collected.
No, because the median does not equal $3.2$.
No, because the data will change with a different sample of $10$ students.

solution:
Solution

When data is collected randomly, there will always be some variation. Since variation occurs, the conclusions based off that data is often uncertain.

Since the principal only took a sample of size 10, we can safely assume the school is larger than 10 students. Therefore, the "average" of the 10 is uncertain to be the average of the whole school.

The principal cannot confidently say that the average GPA of the whole school is 3.2.

Choice 'E' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. 10
students might be able to give us an estimate of the average GPA, but since data is uncertain, it is unlikely to be the average GPA for the whole school.

Choice 'B' is incorrect. Although data that is randomly collected is preferred, it's not the only requirement to estimate the whole school's GPA.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. As stated above, data needs to be collected randomly if we want to use the data in any meaningful way

Choice 'D' is incorrect. It does not specify which "average", or measure of center, the principal wants to use, but since data will vary, he still wouldn't be positive even if the median was 3.2
.
